channel.title: Uncategorized on Matt Jones
channel.description: Recent content in Uncategorized on Matt Jones

item.title: One Click from Danger
item.description: On Monday, the BBC are showing a Panorama investigation called One Click from Danger. It’s like Brasseye never happened.

item.title: Run Around Now
item.description: A Guide to the Iowa Caucuses It’s Runaround!

item.title: Ambiplectrum
item.description: I play a real guitar right-handed, but an air guitar left-handed. The air guitar is actually a right-handed air guitar played upside-down. I string it normally though, of course.

item.title: The Band Remains the Same
item.description: Page, Plant, Jones and Bonham may have plundered the back catalog of various folk and blues artists of the past without due credit, but boy did they do it well. You could argue that this is an activity very much in the folk tradition; the music has freedom, songs get passed from generation to generation, and are interpreted differently. Page is criticised for stealing Bert Jansch’s Black Water Side, but really Page and Jansch were both inspired by Anne Brigg’s interpretation of a folk song which is much older than any of their versions.

item.title: Microsoft trials XP on XO laptop
item.description: Microsoft trials XP on XO laptop From the OLPC community Wiki that’s used for documentation and sharing learning materials, to the software on the XO, everything is open, and that is the project’s strength. Microsoft are just eyeing a new market for their old proprietory software and in so doing are not helping the OLPC project one bit.

item.title: Perl on Rails - Why the BBC Fails at the Internet
item.description: Perl on Rails - Why the BBC Fails at the Internet ... talented, underpaid, and frustrated software engineers at the BBC are forced to make a decision. Either they can produce websites using static HTML, and make a few remote calls to limited Perl functions, decorating their page with SSIs, or they can fight against a reticent and incompetent technology supplier to make use of a crippled and outdated language on servers that more than likely are unable to meet the capacity requirements of a dynamic application being used by the BBC's audience.
